awd_titl_txt: The Science of Success: An Integrative Approach of Experiential Learning and Career Readiness Across STEM Disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
The Science of Success Program at the North Dakota State College of Science (NDSCS) will offer STEM students a comprehensive infrastructure of financial, academic and professional support by utilizing existing NDSCS Student Success resources and by creating a STEM Scholars Scholarship Program, Academic Support Network and Career Success Network. The overall goal of the project is to increase the number of skilled, well-educated, and professional STEM graduates for the statewide and regional in-demand workforce by providing support for 60 STEM students who demonstrate academic talent and financial need. The program aims to unify students enrolled in career and technical STEM programs and liberal arts STEM transfer programs by incorporating experiential learning and integrating career-success skills throughout each student's plan of study. 

The objectives of the Science of Success Program are to: (1) recruit academically talented STEM students with demonstrated financial need, (2) retain 100% of STEM Scholars from their first to second year of study and graduate 90% of STEM Scholars within two years, and (3) integrate career-success skills throughout their plan of study. Retention and graduation rates will be addressed by providing a support network of faculty and peer mentors, early intervention, academic tutoring, and by emphasizing experiential learning within and outside of the classroom. A Career Success Seminar Series will be designed using the 360 Career Success Skills learning modules to provide a platform for students to acquire career-ready skills and to network with industry professionals.  The research component of the project will determine the relationship of each intervention (retention, graduation, engagement, career readiness) to student achievement and professional skill development. The overall impact will be the natural formation of a community of practice that includes industry and four-year institution stakeholders, mentors, support team, alumni, and current students seeking to implement best practices to improve career success.

inst.inst_name: North Dakota State College of Science
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH DAKOTA STATE COLLEGE OF SCIENCE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: North Dakota State College of Science

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Science of Success Program offered students a comprehensive infrastructure of financial, academic, and professional support by leveraging existing NDSCS Student Success resources and by creating the Science of Success Support Network and the Career Success Seminar Series. The Science of Success Program provided scholarships from $1,000 to $10,000 per academic year to 88 students during the funding period: 82 students enrolled in Career and Technical Programs, and 6 students enrolled in Liberal Arts Transfer Programs.

Career and Technical Programs: Architectural Drafting and Estimating Technology, Electrical Technology, Information Systems Administration, Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning and Refrigeration, Land Surveying and Estimating Technology, Precision Machining Technology, Robotics, Automation and Mechatronics Technology, Welding Technology

Liberal Arts Transfer Programs: Biotechnology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Mathematics

The Science of Success Support Network

The Science of Success Program merged the established programs and services designed by NDSCS Student Success with personalized mentoring and support for each scholarship student.

Existing Services. A First Year Experience Course is required for all first-year students to ensure students start on the right path of academic success. Among the topics covered in FYE are campus resources, time management, wellness, study skills, learning styles, and conflict resolution. Academic Counselors and Student Support Specialists offer academic advisement, course planning and career development. The Student Support Specialists work collaboratively with the faculty mentors and students to ensure that concerns are addressed before escalating. Academic Support Services offered free-of-charge expert and peer tutoring.

Science of Success Orientation Event. Establishing personal relationships with our STEM Scholars was an essential component of our Support Network. The orientation event for the new STEM Scholars occurred early in the Fall Semester and served as an important cohort building activity where the new students meet the individuals who will aid in their success: the Management Team, Faculty Mentors, representatives from Student Success, Enrollment Services, Financial Aid, and their peers. The College President, Vice President for Instructional Affairs, Vice President for Student Affairs, and Dean of Instruction regularly attended the event to show their support for the students.

Faculty Mentors. We incorporated critical faculty mentor-student check-in points to enable early tutoring and other interventions to foster academic success. The faculty mentors assisted students in addressing their specific needs and concerns unique to a two-year college student such as course selection, career paths, professional skill development, and transfer procedures to a four-year university.

Career Success Initiatives

The Science of Success Program merged the established programs and services designed by NDSCS Career Services and academic programs with the formation of the Career Success Seminar Series.

Existing Activities. Experiential learning in form of classroom activities, internships, research, creative activity, projects, and professional skill development is a foundation of NDSCS academic programs and the Science of Success Program. In the CTE programs, students are immersed in real-world scenarios and receive hands-on training with cutting-edge equipment used in industry. All CTE scholarship students reported participating in at least one experiential learning opportunity.

Career Success Seminar Series. The seminar series was designed to develop essential career-ready skills and to network with industry professionals who serve as the facilitators. Four key topic areas, communication, self-awareness, responsibility and accountability, and workplace environment, were the foundation for the series. We implemented and modified existing career success modules available through the 360 Manufacturing and Applied Engineering NSF-ATE Regional Center of Excellence. We developed guiding questions for each seminar topic, and the presider used the questions to facilitate the discussion and to emphasize the key concepts. Faculty mentors attended the seminars to show support and participate in the discussion. Two of the four key topic areas were highlighted each academic year, and the connections between the topic areas are constantly reinforced. A networking session either preceded or followed each seminar which allowed for a more personal exchange between students and industry professionals, and further facilitated student reflective learning. Students reported gains in their professional skill development from attending the seminars.

Student Success

The goal of the Science of Success Program was to increase the number of skilled, well-educated, and professional STEM graduates for the statewide and regional workforce by providing students with a comprehensive infrastructure of financial, academic, and professional support. The success was documented by the retention rates, graduation rates, and academic achievement. Two CTE students were selected to the All-North Dakota Academic Team which recognizes the academic achievements and distinguished leadership of community college students. The year one to two retention rate for first year scholarship students was 82% with a three-year graduation rate of 67%, compared to the college-wide retention rate of 70% and graduation rate of 41%.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: William R Shay
